definition: A penalty paid by teams whose total payroll exceeds the luxury tax threshold. The NBA uses this to discourage excessive spending and promote competitive balance.
example: If your payroll is $200M and the tax line is $171M, you pay a progressive tax on the $29M overage.

definition: The first luxury tax threshold ($178M in 2025-26). Teams above this line face restrictions on signing players and making trades.
example: Teams above the first apron cannot use the full Mid-Level Exception.

definition: A more punitive luxury tax threshold ($189M in 2025-26). Teams above this face severe restrictions including frozen draft picks and trade limitations.
example: The Cavaliers are the only team in the second apron this season at $228M payroll.

definition: An additional tax penalty for teams that have paid luxury tax in 3 of the past 4 seasons. The tax rate increases by an additional multiplier.
example: Warriors are repeater tax payers, so they pay 1.5x more in penalties than non-repeaters.

definition: A composite score combining wins, playoff performance, and team efficiency. Used to measure overall team success in this simulator.
example: Performance points = (Wins × 1.2) + (Playoff Wins × 5) + bonuses for efficiency.

definition: The maximum amount teams can spend on player salaries. The 2025-26 cap is approximately $141M (soft cap - teams can exceed it with exceptions).
example: Teams can go over the cap using Bird rights or exceptions like the MLE.

definition: An exception allowing teams over the cap to sign a free agent for approximately $8-12M per year, depending on their cap situation.
example: The Bucks could use their MLE to sign a veteran role player without affecting other roster moves.

definition: Named after Larry Bird, this allows teams to exceed the cap to re-sign their own free agents. Players must have been with the team for 3+ years.
example: The Bucks can offer Giannis any contract amount using his Bird rights, even if over the cap.

definition: Created when a team trades a player without taking back equal salary. Can be used within a year to acquire players without matching salaries.
example: Trading away a $10M player for picks creates a $10M trade exception.

definition: Trading away an expensive player (often with draft picks) to reduce payroll and avoid luxury tax penalties.
example: Trading Kuzma and a 2nd round pick to shed his $23M salary is a classic dump move.

definition: A player contract that ends this season, creating immediate cap flexibility next year.
example: Acquiring expiring contracts helps teams reset their cap situation for the following season.

definition: Predetermined salaries for draft picks based on their draft position. These contracts are team-friendly and below market value.
example: A top-5 pick makes roughly $8-12M in their first year on a rookie scale deal.

definition: Extending a player's contract before it expires. Can lock in stars or negotiate team-friendly deals before they hit free agency.
example: Extending Giannis now prevents him from becoming a free agent and demanding a trade.

definition: Negotiating with a player to pay less than their full contract in exchange for releasing them. Both sides must agree.
example: Buying out a $15M contract for $12M saves $3M in payroll.

definition: The minimum salary a veteran player can be paid, based on years of service. A cheap way to add depth.
example: Signing a 10-year veteran on a minimum deal costs ~$3M but only counts $2M against the cap.

definition: A contract allowing players to split time between the NBA team and G-League affiliate. Costs significantly less than standard deals.
example: Two-way players can be called up for up to 50 NBA games and make ~$500K total.

definition: A free agent whose current team can match any offer from another team. Gives teams leverage to retain young talent.
example: If another team offers your RFA $20M/year, you can match and keep them.

definition: A free agent who can sign with any team. The original team has no right to match offers.
example: When Brook Lopez became a UFA, he freely chose to sign with the Clippers.

definition: How effectively a team scores using the pick-and-roll offensive play. Key metric for evaluating guards and centers.
example: Adding an athletic roll man improves your pick-and-roll points per possession.

definition: How well a team's shooters spread out the defense, creating driving lanes. Teams with good spacing score more efficiently.
example: Trading for an elite shooter opens up the floor for your star to attack the basket.

definition: Points allowed per 100 possessions. Lower is better. Elite defenses have ratings below 108.
example: Adding a rim protector typically improves your defensive rating by 2-4 points.

definition: An estimate of the number of wins contributed by a player. Stars typically have 10+ win shares per season.
example: Giannis averages 12-15 win shares, meaning he's responsible for 12-15 of the Bucks' wins.

definition: Strategic resting of star players to prevent injuries and keep them fresh for playoffs. Controversial but effective.
example: Load managing your stars costs regular season wins but may improve playoff performance.

definition: A team's realistic chances of deep playoff success. Measured by roster talent, health, and playoff experience.
example: Trading for playoff-tested veterans increases your playoff equity even if wins don't jump.

definition: Strategic accumulation and use of draft picks, young players, and cap space to build championship teams.
example: Trading veterans for picks is good asset management if you're rebuilding.
